FacilityName: (24) The McGregor Company Plant Nutrient Center
FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Changed from a Program Level 2 to Program Level 3 and from 1 covered process to 5 covered processes.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The McGregor Company (TMC) Plant Nutrient Center (PNC) Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained TMC staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. 



Covered Process 1 (i.e. Railcar Storage) equipment may include up to five 34,000-gallon railcars.  TMC does not own the railcars and therefore is not responsible for the mechanical integrity of the railcar.  However, trained TMC personnel receive, inspect, and release railcars in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Railcar Operating Procedures.  TMC is responsible for training its personnel in the Railcar Operating Procedures.  Transfer of anhydrous ammonia from the railcars to the storage tanks is considered to be part of Covered Process 2 (i.e. Storage and Handling ? Anhydrous Ammonia).

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Emergency shutoff valve, excess flow valves, pump bypass.  Also, changed from Program Level 2 to Program Level 3 and from 1 covered process to 5 covered processes.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Storage tanks, pumps, process piping, valves, transefer hoses and connections.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The McGregor Company (TMC) Plant Nutrient Center (PNC) Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained TMC staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. 



Covered Process 2 (i.e. Storage and Handling ? Anhydrous Ammonia) equipment includes two stationary storage tanks (i.e. 30,000 gallon and 40,000 gallon) and ancillary pumps, piping, and valves.  The Facility receives bulk shipments of anhydrous ammonia by railcar and NH3 Semi Trucks.  From the stationary storage tanks, the anhydrous ammonia is transferred into NH3 Field Delivery Trucks for transportation to the client location.  Trained TMC personnel perform the transfer of anhydrous ammonia into and out of the stationary storage tanks in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Storage and Handling Operating Procedures.  Trained TMC personnel perform the maintenance on this covered process in accordance with its PSM/RMPr Mechanical Integrity Procedures.  TMC is responsible for training its personnel in these Operating and Maintenance Procedures.  Transfer of anhydrous ammonia from the stationary storage tanks to Covered Process 3 (i.e. Ammonium Polyphosphate Reacting) and Covered Process 4 (i.e. Aqua Ammonia Reacting) is conducted in accordance with those covered process operating procedures.

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Emergency shutoff valve.  Also, changed from Program Level 2 to Program Level 3 and from 1 covered process to 5 covered processes.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Reactor, pumps, process piping, valves, hoses and connections.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The McGregor Company (TMC) Plant Nutrient Center (PNC) Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained TMC staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. 



Covered Process 3 (i.e. Ammonium Polyphosphate Reacting) equipment includes the Reactor and ancillary pumps, piping, and valves.  The reactor is physically connected by process piping to the stationary storage tanks.  Ammonium Polyphosphate (i.e. 10-34-0) is a fertilizer that is manufactured by blending anhydrous ammonia with water and super-phosphoric acid in a ?stationary reactor? (i.e. Ammonium Polyphosphate Reacting).  The Ammonium Polyphosphate Reacting (APP) process equipment is owned and operated by TMC.  The APP does not have any storage capabilities for anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is transferred from one of the two stationary storage tanks by process piping to the APP.  Once the anhydrous ammonia is blended, the anhydrous ammonia becomes inert and therefore the ammonium polyphosphate product is not subject to the PSM/RMPr.  The ammonium polyphosphate product is transferred into stationary storage tanks.  Trained TMC personnel perform the transfer of anhydrous ammonia and operate the APP in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Operating Procedures.  Trained TMC personnel perform the maintenance on this covered process in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Mechanical Integrity Procedures.  TMC is responsible for training its personnel in the Operating and Maintenance Procedures.

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Emergency shutoff valve.  Also, changed from Program Level 2 to Program Level 3 and from 1 covered process to 5 covered processes.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Reactor, pumps, process piping, valves, hoses and connections.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The McGregor Company (TMC) Plant Nutrient Center (PNC) Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained TMC staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. 



Covered Process 4 (i.e. Aqua Ammonium Reacting) equipment includes the Reactor and ancillary pumps, piping, and valves.  The reactor is physically connected by process piping to the stationary storage tanks.  Aqua-ammonia is a fertilizer that is manufactured by blending anhydrous ammonia and water in a ?stationary reactor? (i.e. Aqua Ammonia Reacting) to make a solution that is up to 24% aqua ammonia by weight.  The Aqua Ammonium Reacting (AAR) process equipment is owned and operated by TMC.  The AAR does not have any storage capabilities for anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is transferred from one of the two stationary storage tanks by process piping to the AAR.  After blending, the aqua ammonia product is transferred by piping to one of the four stationary storage tanks located in the liquids storage tank farm.  Because the aqua ammonia product has a concentration of 20% or greater, it is subject to the EPA RMP and therefore the storage of aqua ammonia is also subject to the PSM/RMPr (See Covered Process 5).  Trained Process Operators at PNC perform the transfer of anhydrous ammonia to the AAR, operate the AAR, and then transfer the aqua ammonia to storage in accordance with the AAR Operating Procedures.  Trained TMC personnel perform the maintenance on this covered process in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Mechanical Integrity Procedures.  TMC is responsible for training its personnel in the Operating and Maintenance Procedures.

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Berms and sumps at truck transfer areas.
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Evaluating PHA recommendations.  Also, changed from Program Level 2 to Program Level 3 and from 1 covered process to 5 covered processes.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Storage tanks, pumps, process piping, valves, hoses and connections.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The McGregor Company (TMC) Plant Nutrient Center (PNC) Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained TMC staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. 



Covered Process 5 (i.e. Storage and Handling ? Aqua Ammonia) equipment includes four stationary storage tanks (i.e. 33,500 gallon, 36,000 gallon, and two 35,000 gallon) and ancillary pumps, piping, and valves.  The Facility blends the aqua ammonia in Covered Process 4 (i.e. Aqua Ammonia Reacting) and transfers the aqua ammonia into the stationary storage tanks.  From the stationary storage tanks, the aqua ammonia is transferred into Liquid Tanker Trucks for delivery to clients.  Trained Process Operators manage the aqua ammonia in the stationary storage tanks and perform the transfer of aqua ammonia from the stationary storage tanks to Liquid Tanker Trucks in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Aqua Ammonia Storage and Handling Operating Procedures.  Trained TMC personnel perform the maintenance on this covered process in accordance with its PSM/RMPr Mechanical Integrity Procedures.  TMC is responsible for training its personnel in these Operating and Maintenance Procedures.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: This is a non-responding facility and it coordinates its response activities with the LEPC and local Fire Department. Notification information and procedures are provided in its Contingency Plan.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



This Process Safety Management (PSM) and Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program document (PSM/RMPr) was prepared on behalf of The McGregor Company (TMC) pursuant to the requirements of the Clean Air Act ? 112(r) as codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) at 29 CFR ? 1910.119 and by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) at 40 CFR ?68.  The OSHA PSM and EPA Subpart D RMP standards are applicable to operations in Colfax, WA.  At this Facility, TMC engages in the formulation, distribution and sale of chemicals (i.e. retail) to customers, most of who use TMC's products to support agricultural operations.  



This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia from the Plant Nutrient Center (PNC) located approximately 4 miles west of Colfax, WA at 28232 Endicott Road Colfax, WA 99111.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the PNC to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that PNC has taken to ensure that a response to a release (even though a release is unlikely) will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



TMC is submitting this plan as a "Resubmission" of all applicable sections of the RMP.  Based on its analysis, TMC has revised this RMP to reflect 5 covered processes and has changed the RMP Program Level from 2 to 3.  All relevant sections for a Program 3 RMP Facility have been reviewed and/or updated.  The updates are reflected in both the EPA RMP Submit report and the Facility PSM/RMPr.



FACILITY



The Operations at the PNC Facility consists of agricultural chemical storage and handling, manufacturing, retail sale and distribution.  As related to the PSM/RMPr, the PNC Facility stores and handles two covered chemicals (anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia) at quantities that exceed the threshold

quantity established by EPA, and operates five (5) covered processes that involve storage, handling, and manufacturing of the covered chemicals.  The five covered processes include:



o    Covered Process 1: Railcar Storage

o    Covered Process 2: Anhydrous Ammonia Storage and Handling

o    Covered Process 3: Ammonium Polyphosphate Reacting

o    Covered Process 4: Aqua Ammonia Reacting

o    Covered Process 5: Aqua Ammonia Storage and Handling



The PNC receives anhydrous ammonia by railcar and NH3 Semi Trucks and stores the anhydrous ammonia in one of two stationary storage tanks.  From the stationary storage tanks, the anhydrous ammonia may be transferred to NH3 Field Delivery  

Truck(s) for transportation to the client location, or may be transferred to the Ammonium Polyphosphate Reacting (Covered Process 3) and the Aqua Ammonia Reacting (Covered Process 4) for the blending of ammonium polyphosphate or aqua ammonia.  Because the aqua ammonia is greater than 20% concentration, the storage and handling of the aqua ammonia is also covered under the PSM/RMPr.  TMC trains all of its Process Operators and Maintenance Personnel in the relevant operating and maintenance procedures provided in the PSM/RMPr.



It is important to note that the total quantity of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored at the Facility is 1,152,448 lbs.  The total quantity that RMP Submit calculates is high because Covered Processes 3 and 4 have no actual storage but are connected to the stationary storage tanks whose quantity is included in the 1,152,448 lbs.  Thus the quantity in the storage tanks is counted 3 times rather than only one time as it should be.



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for all five covered processes. The worst case scenario release assumed that all the contents in the largest single vessel were released.  The release was modeled as if the ammonia tank was punctured on the side at the ground level. The resulting

release of ammonia was modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.



Depending on the covered process, the alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario assumes (1) the failure to fully close a vapor valve on a railcar (Covered Process 1), (2) rupture of a transfer hose during a major loading or unloading operation (Covered Processes 2 and 5), and (3) release of anhydrous ammonia from process piping (Covered Processes 3 and 4).  Although these events are classified as an alternative scenario, even an accident of this type is unlikely to occur due to the safety equipment (excess flow devices, emergency shutoff valves, and check valves) and operating procedures that TMC uses to safeguard ammonia transfer operations.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The PNC Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility.  The PNC Manager is assisted by other trained TMC staff, as directed.  The PNC Manager is responsible for ensuring that TMC Staff are properly trained in the implementation of the Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



TMC's PNC is a non-responding facility. TMC has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at the PNC.



CONCLUSION



The Risk Management Plan implemented by The McGregor Company at the PNC complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The RMP will be updated as

PNC adds, deletes, or changes processes. The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the Whitman County LEPC and Fire Department.



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, 6, and 8 of EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the PNC.
